Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Evolution and variability of modern human sleep patterns

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this RAPID project, the investigators will measure melatonin levels and timing of sleep in two non-industrialized populations that are similar except for access to electricity, to understand how sleep is affected by artificial light and the interaction of artificial and natural light exposures. Because power lines are quickly being extended in the research area, this experimental design is possible during a limited window of time before electricity reaches all communities. The research will contribute to our understanding of underlying biological mechanisms and variability of human sleep patterns. The project will support student training, international research collaborations, and public and community science outreach activities, and has potential relevance for understanding sleep problems in industrialized settings.

The investigators will collect data on melatonin levels and sleep timing for individuals in each of two Toba/Qom communities. Participants will wear activity watches and keep diaries to document sleep patterns and quality. Saliva samples will be assayed to determine each individual's daily melatonin onset. The main predictions are that individuals in the community with artificial light will have a later time of daily melatonin onset, that differences will be greatest during the winter, and that any effect of moonlight would be to decrease sleep quality, more so in the population without artificial light. The project will expand our understanding of the spectrum of sleep patterns and sleep-regulatory pressures that may have played distinct roles in human history and evolution, and the ways in which modern societies have modified human sleep patterns.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the last 2 years working under this Award we carried out two studies that address how human ancestral sleep was shaped by natural cycles. We studied Toba-Qom communities in the province of Formosa, Argentina. These indigenous communities have different levels of urbanization: some live in the outskirts of a small town and have 24/7 access to electricity and street lighting whereas others have no access to electricity and live in rural areas. The first study investigated why communities without access to electricity go to bed earlier and sleep longer, which we had demonstrated several years ago. We were able to show that this earlier timing of sleep is in part due to the fact that their 24-h biological clock is delayed relative to the communities with access to electricity. We did this by measuring the timing of release of a hormone, melatonin, which can be measured in saliva a provides a reliable indication of the timing of the biological clock. Communities with access to electricity had a later timing of melatonin release in the evening, indicating that their exposure to artificial light indeed delays their biological clock relative to the communities without access to electricity.

The second study evaluated whether moon phases affect the timing of sleep. Our hypothesis, based on popular stories we heard from these communities, was that during moonlit nights people would sleep less than during nights without moon light, and that this effect would not be present in urban communities with access to electricity. Our data supported this hypothesis showing that rural communities start sleep later and sleep less during moonlit nights than during new moon nights, and this effect is lost in urban communities.

Our project also represented a unique opportunity to strengthen our relationship with the Toba-Qom communities, to talk to them about our findings, and to recruit some members of the communities to help us with logistics of the study, visiting different communities on a regular basis to improve compliance. The project also represented an outstanding opportunity to expose US students to these indigenous communities, their ways of life and the remote geographical area they live in.
